chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of plantar fasciitis
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with plantar fasciitis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with plantar fasciitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Give information on plantar fasciitis.
    • Explain that most people will make a complete recovery within a year.
    • Patient information is available from the NHS website (www.nhs.uk).
  • Give self-care advice to relieve foot pain, promote healing of the fascia, and /or prevent future episodes. Advise the person to:
    • Rest the foot (by avoiding standing or walking for long periods) where possible.
    • Wear shoes with good arch support and cushioned heels (such as laced sports shoes).
    • Avoid walking barefoot.
    • Consider purchasing insoles and heel pads to insert in their shoes, with the aim of correcting foot pronation. Advise that 'magnetic' devices should be avoided.
    • Lose weight if overweight or obese.
  • Give advice on measures to provide symptom relief.
    • Simple analgesics, such as paracetamol (with or without codeine) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), may provide pain relief. See the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues for prescribing information on this analgesics.
    • Advise the person to apply an icepack (covered with a towel) to the foot for 15–20 minutes for symptomatic relief.
    • Recommend self-physiotherapy to stretch the plantar fascia and relieve symptoms.
  • If symptoms are having a significant impact on the person and short-term relief of symptoms is required, consider injection of the plantar fascia with a corticosteroid.
    • Be aware that:
      • The injection is often very painful and post-injection pain may last for several days.
      • Symptoms commonly return within a month following the injection.
      • Rarely a corticosteroid injection can cause fat pad atrophy or plantar fascia rupture.
    • If a corticosteroid injection is considered appropriate, preferably refer for an ultrasound guided injection (if this facility is available locally).
    • If the initial treatment was beneficial but symptoms return, the treatment may be repeated once with a minimum of 6 weeks between injections.
  • Refer people with mild symptoms to a podiatrist or physiotherapist if self-care advice and self-physiotherapy have not been effective after a few months.
    • Consider earlier referral to a podiatrist or physiotherapist for people with more severe symptoms that are having a significant impact on their ability to function normally.
    • Consider referral to an orthopaedic or podiatric surgeon if pain persists following treatment by a podiatrist of physiotherapist. Specialist treatments that may be offered include:
      • Extracorporeal shockwave therapy, a non-invasive treatment that involves passing acoustic shock waves through the affected area.
      • Surgical division of the plantar fascia.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are largely based on the American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons Clinical Consensus Statement: Diagnosis and Treatment of Adult Acquired Infracalcaneal Heel Pain [Schneider, 2018] and on expert opinion in review articles [Orchard, 2012; Thing et al, 2012; Becker, 2018; Luffy, 2018; Tu, 2018; BMJ, 2019].

Giving information on plantar fasciitis
  • This recommendation is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Self-care advice
  • These recommendations are largely based on expert opinion in review articles and on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • Most foot disorders do not require podiatry referral or complex interventions, but can be managed with over-the-counter and home remedies [Becker, 2018].
    • Resting the foot — plantar fasciitis is considered to be an overuse phenomenon, and avoiding high impact activities is sensible. Rest is recommended as a measure to relieve foot pain and promote healing of the fascia [Thing et al, 2012; BMJ, 2019].
    • Good footwear — good footwear is widely recommended by experts [Becker, 2018; Luffy, 2018; Tu, 2018; BMJ, 2019], although there is little or no evidence to support this.  
    • Not walking barefoot — walking barefoot is likely to aggravate foot pain.
    • Orthoses — foot orthoses are widely recommended on the basis that they benefit foot posture and aid fascia healing [Thing et al, 2012]. However, there is little evidence to support this.
      • Evidence from a systematic review and meta-analysis showed that foot orthoses are not superior for improving pain and function compared with sham or other conservative treatment in people with plantar heal pain [Rasenberg, 2018]. A second systematic review and meta-analysis found moderate-quality evidence that foot orthoses are effective at reducing pain in the medium term; however, it was uncertain whether this is a clinically important change [Whittaker, 2018]. Evidence from one small randomized trial suggests magnetic insoles are no more effective than ordinary insoles, so these should be avoided on a cost basis [Winemiller et al, 2003].
      • The American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons states that biomechanical support is safe and effective in the treatment of plantar fasciitis [Schneider, 2018].
    • Weight loss — this recommendation is based on evidence that a higher body mass index is a risk factor for plantar fasciitis [van Leeuwen, 2016].
Symptomatic relief
  • Analgesia
    • Simple analgesics (such as paracetamol and codeine) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have been used historically, although there is a lack of evidence to prove their effectiveness in the treatment of plantar fasciitis.
    • The American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons advises that although it makes sense to treat the acute phase of plantar fasciitis with an NSAID, no published data support its use. Therefore, based on expert opinion and the sparse data, the routine use of NSAIDs is not recommended for treating plantar fasciitis [Schneider, 2018].
    • Expert opinion in a review article is that NSAIDs do not appear to be helpful in managing plantar fasciitis because the condition is a degenerative rather than an inflammatory process [Becker, 2018].
  • Using an ice pack
    • Expert opinion in a review article is that icing is a local pain reducer with virtually no adverse systemic effects [BMJ, 2019]. 
Considering corticosteroid injection
  • Corticosteroid injection is frequently used for plantar fasciitis, but there is limited high-quality evidence to support this treatment.
  • A Cochrane systematic review (search date: March 2017) assessed the effects (benefits and harms) of injected corticosteroids for treating plantar heel pain in adults [David, 2017].
    • Low-quality evidence suggested that local corticosteroid injections compared with placebo or no treatment may slightly reduce heel pain for up to one month but not subsequently.
    • The available evidence for other outcomes of this comparison was very low quality.
    • The authors highlighted that although serious adverse events relating to corticosteroid injection were rare, these were under‐reported and a higher risk cannot be ruled out.
  • A subsequent systematic review and meta-analysis compared corticosteroid injection to any comparator [Whittaker, 2019]. Primary outcomes were pain and function, categorized as short (0–6 weeks), medium (7–12 weeks), or longer term (13–52 weeks).
    • For reducing pain in the short term, corticosteroid injection was more effective than autologous blood injection and foot orthoses. There were no significant findings in the medium term. In the longer term, corticosteroid injection was less effective than dry needling and platelet-rich plasma injection.
    • For reducing pain in the short and medium terms, corticosteroid injection was found to have similar effectiveness to placebo injection.
    • For improving function in the short term, corticosteroid injection was more effective than physical therapy.
    • However, when trials considered to have high risk of bias were excluded, there were no significant findings. The authors concluded that further trials that are of low risk of bias will strengthen this evidence.
When to refer
  • This recommendation is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The recommendation to refer to an orthopaedic or podiatric surgeon if conservative measures fail is based on expert opinion in a review article, which state that reasonable time to refer for surgery would be when conservative measures have been tried for 6–12 months but failed [Thing et al, 2012].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give about self-physiotherapy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Recommend the following stretching exercises to stretch the plantar fascia and relieve symptoms:
    • Achilles tendon and plantar fascia stretch.
      • Advise the person to keep a long towel (or tubigrip) beside their bed. Before they get out of bed, they should loop the towel around their foot, and pull it with the knees straight, causing dorsiflexion, and hold this position for 30 seconds.
      • Repeat three times for each foot.
    • Wall push-up or stretches for the Achilles tendon.
      • Advise the person to place both hands (at shoulder height) on a wall, with staggered feet (one foot in front of the other). The front foot should be approximately 30 cm (12 inches) from the wall. With the front knee bent and the back knee straight, the person should lean towards the wall, until a tightening is felt in the calf of the back leg, and then ease off. Repeat ten times.
      • The exercise above is repeated, but the back foot is brought forward a little so that the back knee is slightly bent. Repeat ten times.
      • Repeat both sets of stretches twice a day.
    • Stair stretches for the Achilles tendon and plantar fascia.
      • Advise the person to stand facing upstairs using the stair-rail for support. The feet should be positioned so that both heels are off the end of the step, with the legs slightly apart. The heels are lowered, keeping the knees straight, until a tightening is felt in the calf. The position is held for 20–60 seconds, and then the heels are raised back to neutral.
      • Repeat the exercise six times, at least twice a day.
    • Dynamic stretches for the plantar fascia.
      • While seated, the person should be advised to roll the arch of their foot over a rolling pin, a drinks can, or a tennis ball. They should allow the foot and ankle to move in all directions as it rolls over the object.
      • The exercise is continued for a few minutes or until there is some discomfort.
      • Repeat the exercise at least twice a day.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on trial evidence [Rathleff, 2015; Huffer, 2017], the American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons Clinical Consensus Statement: Diagnosis and Treatment of Adult Acquired Infracalcaneal Heel Pain [Schneider, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles [Becker, 2018; Luffy, 2018; Tu, 2018; BMJ, 2019]. The specific exercises recommended are in line with recommendations issued by the Arthritis Research Campaign for people with plantar fasciitis [ARC, 2004].

  • Stretching is safe, effective, and low-cost treatment for plantar fasciitis [Becker, 2018; Luffy, 2018; Schneider, 2018]. It is likely effective because it counteracts shortening of the plantar fascia [Becker, 2018].
  • A randomized controlled trial found that plantar fascia strengthening exercises are superior to other stretching exercises for pain and function in the short term, but there were no differences between the groups at six and 12 months [Rathleff, 2015]. A systematic review found low-quality evidence to support strengthening exercises for plantar fasciitis, although it is unclear if all strengthening regimens have comparable benefits [Huffer, 2017].
